> The idea of automatically generating tests is incompatible with the 
JUnit (and xUnit) philosophy. JUnit is a framework in which humans 
write tests; it is not a tool that writes tests.
> 
> An interesting question for you: how do you expect any program to 
know the expected result for each code path? The key point of tests 
is to compare an expected result to the actual result. How is it 
possible for a non-human to know the expected result?
> 

I think one way is to use assertion or post-condition to check the 
validity of the execution. Another way to do is to automatically 
detect program anomalies. This is actually a purpose of my project. 
Running the program with a large set of test case. For the execution 
to construct possible program invariant. If some test case cause the 
execution violates the deduced program invariant, a program bug might 
be found. That's why I want a tool for automatically generating test 
case. 

thanks
